docs.lead_paragraph: CARRYING a suitcase containing 45 pounds of Earth's Best baby food, a portable crib and seven pieces of luggage, the Pavlon-Blum family took off last summer for a five-week trip to Europe. The baby food was to insure 5-month-old Ethan would eat right, and the crib would give him the comfort of the same bed every night. ''We were pretty sure we would find acceptable baby food once in Hungary, but we weren't sure about Poland,'' says Jerry Pavlon-Blum, who, along with his life partner, Myron, is in the process of adopting Ethan.

headline.main: Couples Wary on Same Sex Adoptions

docs.abstract: Thousands of gay and lesbian couples are raising children in New York State since court decision last year that stated that any couple, homosexual or hetrosexual, do not have to be married to adopt child; photo (M)
docs.snippet: CARRYING a suitcase containing 45 pounds of Earth's Best baby food, a portable crib and seven pieces of luggage, the Pavlon-Blum family took off last summer for a five-week trip to Europe. The baby food was to insure 5-month-old Ethan would eat...

docs.lead_paragraph: LOOKING to a future where far more people will require long-term care, the Government is beginning to encourage Americans to pay for it themselves. The carrot being offered is a tax deduction for individuals and employers on the purchase of long-term-care insurance. The stick is criminal penalties for some people who, instead of financing their own long-term care, try to become eligible for Government-paid care by shifting assets to family members or trusts. Officials and health care economists said the new incentives, which take effect on Jan. 1, herald sweeping changes in public policy. The Federal Government and states face daunting growth in entitlement programs like Medicaid that will soon be overrun by graying baby boomers and their parents.
docs.abstract: New Federal law offering tax deductions for purchase of long-term-care insurance, and penalties for asset-shifting to qualify for Medicaid, discusssed; Kennedy-Kassebaum bill may allow middle-class people to plan for such care themselves; employers will be able to deduct cost of providing long-term-care coverage, as with medical benefits; individuals may also take deductions, but consumer advocates advise close scrutiny of benefits and costs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: They did things that mattered. Some had their hands on the levers of power, and some were found to have had their hands in the till. Some of them were big people doing big things, and others were ordinary people suddenly doing extraordinary things. Some were people caught up and swept along by events.
docs.abstract: Many New Jerseyans left their mark on the state and the nation over the last 20 years, among them Richard J Hughes, Brendan T Byrne, Bill Bradley, the gas station attendant of the 1979 gasoline crunch, Harrison A Williams Jr, Thomas H Kean, Marsha Stern, Robert N Wilentz, the 'yuppies,' Karen Ann Quinlan, Phil Simms, Baby M, Joe Clark, Jim Florio, John Budzash, Gerald McCann, Gary Spath, Toni Morrison, Emily Mann and Christine Todd Whitman (L)
